üëç zutshiy
:cucumberbdd: mlvandijk
zutshiy
2019-04-09 06:58:44

*Thread Reply:* Ok so the Clock in Java8 itself is based off of on System.currentMillis() so that's the maxium precision we have with it (Java9 Clock has more precision). I am assuming we still need the time() in nanos besides timeInMillis() ? In which case I found out I can extend the clock to allow for nanosecond precision as well

zutshiy
2019-04-09 06:58:59

*Thread Reply:* Cuz you said that the steps are more granular

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:17:51

*Thread Reply:* We shouldn't need either as we can use Instant. Only in the events it would be nice to retain the methods .

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:19:41

*Thread Reply:* Instant would also only give us accuracy with millis. Is that ok then?

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:20:01

*Thread Reply:* Instant is in nano's I think

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:20:29

*Thread Reply:* > The range of an instant requires the storage of a number larger than a long. To achieve this, the class stores a long representing epoch-seconds and an int representing nanosecond-of-second, which will always be between 0 and 999,999,999. The epoch-seconds are measured from the standard Java epoch of 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z where instants after the epoch have positive values, and earlier instants have negative values. For both the epoch-second and nanosecond parts, a larger value is always later on the time-line than a smaller value.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:20:33

*Thread Reply:* https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/index.html?java/time/Instant.html

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:20:35

*Thread Reply:* Instant.now() uses the underlying Clock only

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:20:45

*Thread Reply:* Which uses underlying System.millis

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:21:28

*Thread Reply:* Yes, it has a higher range, so we can make it granular to nanos by extending clock, but it dsnt have the precision by default i think

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:22:11

*Thread Reply:* >The Java SE 8 specification for java.time.Clock states that "The system factory methods provide clocks based on the best available >system clock. This may use System.currentTimeMillis(), or a higher resolution clock if one is available.". In JDK 8 the implementation >of the clock returned was based on System.currentTimeMillis(), and thus has only a millisecond resolution.

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:22:30

*Thread Reply:* ah, so that's how you quote something

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:22:50

*Thread Reply:* Yeah

&gt; Text here
zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:23:00

*Thread Reply:* Nice

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:23:26

*Thread Reply:* Anyway, so what do you think? Remove time() entirely or extend the clock with a NanoClock and use that?

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:26:36

*Thread Reply:* Yes. Clock.instant should be fine.

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:29:20

*Thread Reply:* So nothing in nanos, right?

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 07:40:35

*Thread Reply:* Instant and Duration everywhere, unless we have to represent it as a number in a report. Then use what ever is used in that report. If there isn't enough accuracy that is okay.

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:53:49

*Thread Reply:* Ok, I could just use duration for TimeService.time() then. Thanks

zutshiy
2019-04-09 07:54:01

*Thread Reply:* Sorry I might have more doubts so i ll just discuss them here, hope thats fine

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:20:03

*Thread Reply:* No worries.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:20:18

*Thread Reply:* This is not a simple replacement.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:21:24

*Thread Reply:* It's okay to do things slightly different as long as the end result is acceptable.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:21:24

*Thread Reply:* And as long as Clock is injected into the event bus people can still add more accurate clocks

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:22:23

*Thread Reply:* > Ok, I could just use duration for TimeService.time() then. Thanks

I don't think that's quite right. A duration still has to be created from two instants.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:23:18

*Thread Reply:* Duration.between(startInstant, stopInstant);

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:24:11

*Thread Reply:* The nice part is that by avoiding primitives like int/long we don't have to worry about the precision too much anymore.

üëç zutshiy
mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:25:09

*Thread Reply:* Granted, they're not SI seconds, but that's not what we're after anyway.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-09 12:32:56

*Thread Reply:* And for me the primary object isn't so much to provide accurate time as it is to provide adequate time.

I'm trying to reduce the amount of custom code mostly.

zutshiy
2019-04-09 17:17:59

*Thread Reply:* >Duration.between(startInstant, stopInstant);

Yes that's how I meant it, sorry.

zutshiy
2019-04-09 17:20:20

*Thread Reply:* >I'm trying to reduce the amount of custom code mostly.

I understand. Well this is interesting to do anyway, I hadn't worked with Clock before. It's quite convenient.

2019-04-16 07:48:52

zutshiy
2019-05-04 08:07:25

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje I raised a PR. There's probably still a some stuff that needs to be updated, so let me know whenever you get the time to take a look:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1620

gazler22 (https://github.com/gazler22)
#1620 Java 8 Time API Migration
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Migrating the current code to use Java 8 Time API fields instead of the currently used primitive fields.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>The long fields <code>time</code>, <code>timeStampMillis</code> and <code>duration</code> have been replaced by <code>Instant</code> and <code>Duration</code> respectively.</p> <p>These values can now be used instead of older primitives to allow for better representation of time and duration in cucumber without having to worry about precision or granularity.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>To allow for more consistent time measurements and reduce custom code.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>All the JUnits have been updated accordingly to use <code>Instant</code> and <code>Duration</code>.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>‚òê Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue). ‚òëÔ∏é New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). ‚òê Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>‚òëÔ∏é I've added tests for my code. ‚òê My change requires a change to the documentation. ‚òê I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
Assignees
gazler22
Labels
Core, Java 8
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
zutshiy
2019-05-04 08:07:35

*Thread Reply:* And sorry about the delay, its been a very busy month so I didn't get much time to work on this

zutshiy
2019-05-04 08:08:31

*Thread Reply:* I have deprecated the older methods and updated all the JUnits accordingly. The whole time, timeStampMillis and duration have been replaced by Instant and Duration everywhere.

zutshiy
2019-05-04 08:09:53

*Thread Reply:* For now, I didn't inject Clock anywhere since it didn't seem like I need to

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:36:09

*Thread Reply:* Hey! @mpkorstanje

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:37:05

*Thread Reply:* So i am going to update the JunitFormatter to use Duration.ofMillis(1L) and then divide result.getDuration.toNanos() / 1000000000 to get the desired result in seconds.

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:37:12

*Thread Reply:* is that good?

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:38:51

*Thread Reply:* I was actually trying to simply use result.getDuration.getSeconds() to get the seconds directly in decimalformat but it always rounds it to 0 since the time is 0.003s. Can't figure out any way to not rounding it when getting the seconds, would you have any idea?

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:43:02

*Thread Reply:* I think divide is the only way

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:43:22

*Thread Reply:* And yes, its good

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:43:32

*Thread Reply:* Oh. Ok. Thanks

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:43:58

*Thread Reply:* Or maybe

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:44:08

*Thread Reply:* Weird tho, i would think we could format the duration to get it in decimals

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:44:19

*Thread Reply:* yea?

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:44:23

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible to format the duration directly?

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:44:37

*Thread Reply:* haha, yea i've been googling the same thing

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:44:59

*Thread Reply:* the toString() does give you PT0.003S

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:45:27

*Thread Reply:* But i cant seem to find a way to format it to 0.003. DateTimeFormatter only accepts Temporals

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:46:53

*Thread Reply:* Let me get my laptop out

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:47:17

*Thread Reply:* sure

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:51:20

*Thread Reply:* Looks like it doesn't exist yet in Java 8. Java 9 is getting there

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:51:53

*Thread Reply:* Best we can do for now is declare the constant as NANOS_PER_SECONDS = TimeUnit.SECONDS.toNanos(1);

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:53:41

*Thread Reply:* found something in apache commons library

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:53:49

*Thread Reply:* this works : DurationFormatUtils.formatDuration(result.getDuration().toMillis(), "s.SSS")

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:54:09

*Thread Reply:* but it requires the apache-commons dependency to be added to the pom. want me to use it?

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:54:59

*Thread Reply:* No. That means everybody has that dependency during their tests.

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:55:13

*Thread Reply:* And it may conflict with their own version.

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:55:38

*Thread Reply:* Ah, i see. Yes that makes sense

zutshiy
2019-05-27 10:55:47

*Thread Reply:* ok, i ll stick to the division then. let me update the PR

mpkorstanje
2019-05-27 10:55:55

*Thread Reply:* Cheers!

mpkorstanje
2019-04-11 13:56:05

*Thread Reply:* I came up with a solution for a bunch of spring issues.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1604

The problem is, I don't quite know if it works and I don't have the time to try it all out.

mpkorstanje (https://github.com/mpkorstanje)
#1604 [Spring] WIP: Use TestContextManager
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Spike for fixing <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1582">#1582</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1582">#1582</a> and <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1470">#1470</a>.</p> <p>TODO:</p> <p>‚òê Deprecate <code>txn</code> steps ‚òê Deprecate the use of <code>appliction.xml</code> ‚òê Handle absence of annotated class ‚òê Fix all the docs!</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-04-11 14:00:56

*Thread Reply:* Spring uses TestExecutionListeners to prep instances of junit tests. This makes @Autowired and other annotations work.

I used a trick to make it work for Cucumber which has multiple instances (because we have multiple step def classes).

I wrote a test to check if it works with @MockBean. But to do this properly I would need a test to confirm it works with all different TestExecutionListeners.

If you want you could look up all different TestExecutionListeners and write a test for them.

Cameron
2019-04-12 00:06:42

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the heads up, I‚Äôll check it out tonight

2019-05-07 11:52:49

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:24:37

@Aslak Helles√∏y I want to give cucumber-jvm:4.3.0 until June or so to burn all the last few bugs out. Then we're going to merge develop-v5 master and pick up the last few open items in the 5.0.0 mile stone.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/milestone/7

I've moved all the things we don't strictly need for Java 9+ to the 5.x.x milestone.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-04-15 13:27:13

How do you feel about including Gherkin 6 in that release @mpkorstanje? Too much?

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:29:56

Yes.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:31:37

The module system can kill Cucumber JVM adoption.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:32:09

In the long run so I'd like to at least have one major version without the complications of Gherkin 6.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:33:36

I'm also quite worried about the impact it will have on the existing tool chains. All custom formatters are now kinda used to the current implementation but it's leaking quite a bit of Gherkin 5.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:37:43

Sorry. Let me make that a bit more organized.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:40:06

Currently there are two tool chains:

Cucumber --> Some Formatter --> Some report Cucumber --> Json formatter --> Some report

Cucumber v5 will break the first tool chain. When we introduce Gherkin v6. We break the second tool chain.

And it'd be bad to break both at the same time. It would mean that nobody would be able to get started with Cucumber v5 and have a usable working tool in their organisation.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:41:50

We could mitigate the first breakage by starting to deprecate the events in v4 already, but that will take time and effort (and as it personally doesn't affect me that much, I'm not interested in putting too much time into that).

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:43:47

We could start doing the same deprecations for other parts of the system too. But the same reasoning applies.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:46:55

What I am thinking of doing though is writing a road map of sort. It'd bit more a map then the itinerary the usual road map is. It would be a dependency graph of contributions people can make to make the upgrade from v4 to v5 smoother. In other words, if other people care about a smooth upgrade process, they can put the work in to make it happen.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:50:21

Aside from the binary executable problem, the problem with Gherkin V6 is that Gherkin V5 is quite deeply embedded into our public API. There is no easy migration there.

So that would keep that strategy I mentioned earlier from working.

mpkorstanje
2019-04-15 13:54:37

The module system was a pretty big change in the Java eco system. The impact isn't quite there yet, but if we don't start to behave quickly it will become a problem.

So given that I would like to give people at least a way to step into a better behaved version of Cucumber with minimal pain (beyond renaming packages and fixing their custom formatters).

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-04-15 14:28:31

Thanks @mpkorstanje - that makes sense

Chris McC
2019-06-24 09:22:58

@Chris McC has joined the channel

Chris McC
2019-06-24 09:26:22

I'm interested in helping out with the Junit5 / Spring5 support.

Is there something I can work on? New to the Cucumber project but been working with Java for 7+ years.

mlvandijk
2019-06-24 09:44:11

@Chris McC you could have a look at open issues on GitHub. And otherwise @mpkorstanje should be able to help you get started.

mpkorstanje
2019-06-24 10:03:44

@Chris McC I'm holding of on JUnit 5 untill I have Cucumber v5 released.

To make JUnit 5 possible Cucumber change refactor the way it scans for classes and resources.

This will be easier to do once we have Java 8.

See: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1526

Spring 5 already works.

However anything that relies on test life cycle events such as @MockBean and @SpyBean will not work.

I've tried a POC to see if I could make it work using multiple TestContextManagers. Once for each glue class.

It kinda works. But for this too I'm holding off untill I have Cucumber v5 done.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1604

#1526 Replace ResourceIterable with standard Java solutions
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
#1604 [Spring] WIP: Use TestContextManager
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-06-24 10:04:23

Though that is mostly because I can't spread myself too thin.

mpkorstanje
2019-06-24 10:05:00

Other then that, any of these issues could use help:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22Help+Wanted%22

Chris McC
2019-06-24 16:39:18

Coolio. Might take a gander at #1458 over the next few days.

mpkorstanje
2019-06-24 23:45:46

Grweat! If you do, use the develop-v5 branch. It has some of the plumbing problems solved already.

Shivam Pratap Singh
2019-06-29 00:47:32

@Shivam Pratap Singh has joined the channel

mpkorstanje
2019-06-30 05:02:58

@Chris McC I had to do a little poc to see if this wouldn't require something that would have us release v6 immediately after v5. Making it work for annotation based steps is doable. Making it work for Lambda based steps is a bit trickier. The Lambda based parameter types would need to be cleaned up after every run. However the type registry only allows parameter types to be added currently. You may find this useful:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1677

mpkorstanje (https://github.com/mpkorstanje)
#1677 WIP Allow parameter types access to test context
<p>See <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1458">#1458</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
Tomasz Wojtu≈Ñ
2019-07-02 06:05:47

@Tomasz Wojtu≈Ñ has joined the channel

Tomasz Wojtu≈Ñ
2019-07-02 06:06:27

Hey, @mpkorstanje, any particular reason you removed Scenario.getSourceTagNames() in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/commit/9f6b030943600213e522fe44233f65ca15f9f22 ? It blocks me from moving from cucumber.api.Scenario to io.cucumber.core.api.Scenario

mpkorstanje
2019-07-02 06:13:44

*Thread Reply:* Yes! It was added for compatibility with Capyabera some time in the past. But we no longer support JRuby.

I can't work out what people would use it for. And as I was explaining to BB earlier I don't think there are any valid use cases.

https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C5YHPPJMP/p1561973712145300

I wouldn't mind adding it back at all. But I would like to know the use case. So what are you using it for?

Benjamin Bischoff (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/UBZAJRRT4)
<p>Hi there, how do you get the sourceTagNames now that it is not included in <code>io.cucumber.core.api.Scenario</code> anymore?</p>

Benjamin Bischoff
2019-07-03 00:28:31

*Thread Reply:* @Tomasz Wojtu≈Ñ The variants are exactly what we are using it for at the moment. Also for our framework's slack plugin (e.g. @author:slackUserName)

mpkorstanje
2019-07-05 09:37:13

*Thread Reply:* > Some other option to receive list of all scenario tags should work as well for us, but I don't know any.

@bearded.qa depends a bit on what you do with the tags. If you are using them for reporting purposes I would recommend looking at the plugin system.

You can use any TestCaseEvent e.g. TestCaseFinished event to get the current TestCase and its tags.

If it is another use case I'd be interested in hearing about it.

mpkorstanje
2019-07-07 23:35:48

*Thread Reply:* @bearded.qa would you be able to elaborate? ‚òùÔ∏è

bearded.qa
2019-07-08 00:39:41

*Thread Reply:* I'm using it in two cases:

  1. In before hook, I'm getting all scenario's tags to check if test should be run on mobile. I need to check if ignorecase @mobile is present o n tags' list.
  2. Galen reporting: GalenTestInfo.fromString(scenario.getName(), tags) require list of tags and scenario name.
mpkorstanje
2019-07-08 00:46:09

*Thread Reply:* For the second case have you considered using a Plugin?

2019-07-08 00:58:42

2019-07-08 01:22:18

Benjamin Bischoff
2019-07-08 01:23:13

mpkorstanje
2019-07-08 04:04:07

mpkorstanje
2019-07-08 04:06:12

*Thread Reply:* @bearded.qa it's not so difficult. Friend of mine in wrote a blog about it:

https://blog.jdriven.com/2019/01/cucumber-jvm-plugin/

This is for unused steps but you can do the same with test outcomes.

JDriven Blog
Cucumber-JVM plugin to find unused steps
Cucumber-JVM is a framework for writing end to end tests in natural language, with each line backed by a Java method. Each Java method has a regular expression of natural language lines to match, and
Original URL: https://blog.jdriven.com/2019/01/cucumber-jvm-plugin/
mpkorstanje
2019-07-08 09:21:17

*Thread Reply:* Okay. Found a usecase.

Hooks work more or less automatically when they're in the glue path. Plugins always need to be enabled.

mpkorstanje
2019-07-08 09:25:03

*Thread Reply:* So you can't make a drop in configuration dependency with plugins yet.

:cucumberbdd: Benjamin Bischoff

2019-07-09 01:39:09

bearded.qa
2019-07-10 03:39:06

Hi @mpkorstanje, is it possible to release 4.5.4 with getSourceTagNames() being restored?

mpkorstanje
2019-07-10 03:52:01

*Thread Reply:* Yes. But I'm not sure if I'm able to find 30 minutes this week to do it.

mpkorstanje
2019-07-10 03:52:39

*Thread Reply:* If you've cloned the repo via SSH you could try to use:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/master/RELEASING.md

RELEASING.md
<pre><code>Releasing ========= The process of deploying to maven central has been automated based on the [Complete guide to continuous deployment to maven central from Travis CI](&lt;http://www.debonair.io/post/maven-cd/&gt;) and will be executed whenever a non-snapshot version is committed. ## Check [![Build Status](&lt;https://travis-ci.org/cucumber/cucumber-jvm.svg?branch=master&gt;)](&lt;https://travis-ci.org/cucumber/cucumber-jvm&gt;) ## Is the build passing? </code></pre> <p>git checkout master</p> <pre><code> Also check if you can upgrade any dependencies: </code></pre> <p>mvn versions:display-dependency-updates</p> <pre><code> ## Prepare for release ## Replace version numbers in: ** `CHANGELOG.md` Then run (replace X.Y.Z below with the next release number): </code></pre> <p>git commit -am "Prepare for release X.Y.Z"</p> <pre><code> ## Make the release ## Now release everything: </code></pre> <p>mvn release:clean release:prepare -DautoVersionSubmodules=true -Darguments="-DskipTests=true" </p> <pre><code> Travis will now deploy everything. Once travis is done go into [Nexus](&lt;https://oss.sonatype.org/&gt;) and inspect, close and release the staging repository. It is preferable to use the automated deployment process over the manual process. However should &lt;a href="http://travis.ci"&gt;travis.ci&lt;/a&gt; fail or should the need arise to setup another continuous integration system the [Manual deployment](#manual-deployment) section describes how this works. ## Last bits ## Wait for the release to show up on maven central. Then update the dependency in example projects: ** &lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-java-skeleton&gt; Update the cucumber-jvm version in the documentation project: ** &lt;https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io&gt; The cucumber-jvm version for the docs is specified in the docs [versions.yaml](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io/blob/master/data/versions.yaml&gt;) All done! Hurray! # Manual deployment # It is preferable to use the automated deployment process over the manual process. The deployment process of `cucumber-jvm` is based on [Deploying to OSSRH with Apache Maven](&lt;http://central.sonatype.org/pages/apache-maven.html#deploying-to-ossrh-with-apache-maven-introduction&gt;). This process is nearly identical for both snapshot deployments and releases. Whether a snapshot deployment or release is executed is determined by the version number. To make a release you must have the `&lt;a href="mailto:devs@cucumber.io"&gt;devs@cucumber.io&lt;/a&gt;` GPG private key imported in gpg2. </code></pre> <p>gpg --import devs-cucumber.io.key</p> <pre><code> Additionally upload privileges to the Sonatype repositories are required. See the [OSSRH Guide](&lt;http://central.sonatype.org/pages/ossrh-guide.html&gt;) for instructions. Then an administrator will have to grant you access to the cucumber repository. Finally both your OSSRH credentials and private key must be setup in your `~/.m2/settings.xml` - for example: </code></pre> <p>&lt;settings&gt; &lt;servers&gt; &lt;server&gt; &lt;id&gt;ossrh&lt;/id&gt; &lt;username&gt;sonatype-user-name&lt;/username&gt; &lt;password&gt;sonatype-password&lt;/password&gt; &lt;/server&gt; &lt;/servers&gt; &lt;profiles&gt; &lt;profile&gt; &lt;id&gt;ossrh&lt;/id&gt; &lt;activation&gt; &lt;activeByDefault&gt;true&lt;/activeByDefault&gt; &lt;/activation&gt; &lt;properties&gt; &lt;gpg.executable&gt;gpg2&lt;/gpg.executable&gt; &lt;gpg.useagent&gt;true&lt;/gpg.useagent&gt; &lt;/properties&gt; &lt;/profile&gt; &lt;profile&gt; &lt;id&gt;sign-with-cucumber-key&lt;/id&gt; &lt;properties&gt; &lt;gpg.keyname&gt;dev-cucumber.io-key-id&lt;/gpg.keyname&gt; &lt;/properties&gt; &lt;/profile&gt; &lt;/profiles&gt; &lt;/settings&gt;</p> <pre><code> # Deploy the release # </code></pre> <p>mvn release:perform -Psign-source-javadoc -DskipTests=true</p> <pre><code> </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-eclipse">cucumber/cucumber-eclipse</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-07-14 03:12:28

Just to double check, but does the eclipse plugin support cucumber expressions yet or do you have to use regex?

Tim te Beek
2019-07-14 05:01:58

according to @Quentin Vandekerckhove in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-eclipse/issues/368#issuecomment-510475822 > the plugin have its own implementation to resolve glue and gherkin analysis. This is an issue. Idealy, the plugin should delegate all works to cucumber itself.

qvdk (https://github.com/qvdk)
Comment on #368 .feature doesn't work with import from io.cucumber but work with cucumber.api
<p>Hi <a href="https://github.com/timtebeek">@timtebeek</a></p> <p>The upgrade of cucumber libraries will not solve this issue.<br /> Unfortunatelly, the plugin does not delegate the work to the cucumber library itself. Presently, the plugin have its own implementation to resolve glue and gherkin analysis.<br /> This is an issue.<br /> Idealy, the plugin should delegate all works to cucumber itself. The user should be able to choose its cucumber version as the JDK and JRE can be added in Eclipse. Then, the plugin should play with the selected version of cucumber.</p> <p>For now, as a workaround, you need to play with <code>cucumber.eclipse.steps.jdt.JavaStepDefinitionsProvider</code>. Its job is to parse Java files to search gherkin step definition implementations.</p> <p>You will see in the first lines:</p> <pre><code>private final Pattern cukeAnnotationMatcher = Pattern.compile("cucumber\\.api\\.java\\.([a-z_]+)\\.(.**)$"); private static final String CUCUMBER_API_JAVA = "cucumber.api.java."; private static final String CUCUMBER_API_JAVA8 = "cucumber.api.java8."; private static final String REGEX_JAVA8_CUKEAPI = "cucumber\\.api\\.java8\\.(.**)"; </code></pre> <p>This constants are used in this class to search the imports of <code>Given</code>, <code>When</code>, and other Gherkin keywords. Thus to be compliant with those of the Cucumber 5.x, the plugin should be able to parse both, or to detect the cucumber version used to search only the right packages.</p> <p>Hope that helps.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-eclipse">cucumber/cucumber-eclipse</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-07-14 06:59:59

mpkorstanje

Reki

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-07 03:14:13

@Anton Deryabin has joined the channel

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-07 04:31:12

Hi, I have a question about https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1705. When I try run sample from Current Behavior part of the issue, I get It appears you did not register a data table type. error. Should I register custom data typy by myself or there is some docstring to json conversion under the hood?

mpkorstanje (https://github.com/mpkorstanje)
#1705 Use dedicated DocStringTypeRegistry for doc string transforms
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Cucumber uses the <code>DatatTableTypeRegistry</code> to convert doc strings. This is rather confusing and ignores the type provided with the doc string.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; Context</strong></p> <p>With <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1458">#1458</a> and <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/851">#851</a> implemented it will be quite hard to explain how doc strings are converted. So it would be better to do it properly.</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>Given some gherkin</p> <pre><code>Given a doc string """json {hello:"world"} """ </code></pre> <p>And a step definition:</p> <pre><code>@Given("a doc string") public void a_doc_string(JsonNode json){ } </code></pre> <p>In the <code>StepExpressionFactory</code> Cucumber will try to transform this string into JSON by turning the docstring into a 1x1 table and using the <code>DataTableTypeRegistry</code> to convert it to an object of the right target type.</p> <pre><code>DocStringTransformer&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; docStringTransform = new DocStringTransformer&amp;lt;Object&amp;gt;() { @Override public Object transform(String docString) { Type targetType = tableOrDocStringType.resolve(); if (Object.class.equals(targetType)) { return docString; } List&amp;lt;List&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&amp;gt; raw = singletonList(singletonList(docString)); return DataTable.create(raw, StepExpressionFactory.this.tableConverter).convert(targetType, transpose); } }; </code></pre> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p>Cucumber uses a <code>DocStringTypeRegistry</code> in which transformations for each document type can be registered or where a default doc string transformer (document, type) -&gt; Object can be registered.</p>
Labels
Data Tables, Feature Request
Milestone
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/milestone/8">5.x.x</a>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
Tim te Beek
2019-08-07 04:45:58

*Thread Reply:* best to ask in <#C5YHPPJMP|help-cucumber-jvm>

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-07 04:49:47

*Thread Reply:* ok, thank you

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-14 05:44:00

Hi everyone. I am trying to implement this feature https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1705, and look like I need to commit to https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/cucumber-expressions/java/src/main/java/io/cucumber/cucumberexpressions repo and to the cucumber-jvm repo together. Is this ok, or I am doing something wrong?

#1705 Use dedicated DocStringTypeRegistry for doc string transforms
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-14 05:47:06

Hi @Anton Deryabin - thanks for contributing! I‚Äôm not sure I understand why implementing 1705 requires a change to cucumber-expressions?

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-14 06:03:31

Ok, I'll try to explain: I register custom docstring type like this:

public class TypeRegistryConfiguration implements TypeRegistryConfigurer {
    @Override
    public void configureTypeRegistry(TypeRegistry typeRegistry) {
        typeRegistry.defineDocStringType(new ParameterType&lt;&gt;("json", "\\{.**\\}", JsonNode.class, (String s) -&gt; new ObjectMapper().readTree(s)));
    }

Then, in the transform method I have:

Type targetType = tableOrDocStringType.resolve();
 if (Object.class.equals(targetType)) {
        return docString;
 }
 ParameterType parameterType = docStringTypeRegistry.lookUpByContentType(contentType);

ParameterType's function transform is not public, it's default scope, so I can't use it to transform String to JsonNode. I thought, if I can create transformer or something, which will be in the same package with ParameterType, and this transformer can use this function to transform string to JsonNode

mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:08:09

You're looking somewhat in the wrong direction.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:08:54

This would be the best place to start: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/master/core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/stepexpression/StepExpressionFactory.java

core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/stepexpression/StepExpressionFactory.java
<pre><code>package io.cucumber.core.stepexpression; import io.cucumber.core.exception.CucumberException; import io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.Expression; import io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.UndefinedParameterTypeException; import io.cucumber.datatable.DataTable; import io.cucumber.datatable.DataTableTypeRegistryTableConverter; import java.lang.reflect.Type; import java.util.List; import static java.util.Collections.singletonList; public final class StepExpressionFactory { private final io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.ExpressionFactory expressionFactory; private final DataTableTypeRegistryTableConverter tableConverter; public StepExpressionFactory(TypeRegistry registry) { this.expressionFactory = new io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.ExpressionFactory(registry.parameterTypeRegistry()); this.tableConverter = new DataTableTypeRegistryTableConverter(registry.dataTableTypeRegistry()); } public StepExpression createExpression(String expressionString) { if (expressionString == null) throw new NullPointerException("expression can not be null"); Expression expression = expressionFactory.createExpression(expressionString); RawTableTransformer&amp;lt;DataTable&amp;gt; toDataTable = raw -&amp;gt; DataTable.create(raw, tableConverter); DocStringTransformer&amp;lt;Object&amp;gt; toDocString = (String input) -&amp;gt; input; return new StepExpression(expression, toDocString, toDataTable); } public StepExpression createExpression(String expressionString, Type tableOrDocStringType) { return createExpression(expressionString, new ResolvedType(tableOrDocStringType), false); } public StepExpression createExpression(String expressionString, TypeResolver tableOrDocStringType) { return createExpression(expressionString, tableOrDocStringType, false); } public StepExpression createExpression(String expressionString, final Type tableOrDocStringType, final boolean transpose) { return createExpression(expressionString, new ResolvedType(tableOrDocStringType), transpose); } public StepExpression createExpression(String expressionString, final TypeResolver tableOrDocStringType, final boolean transpose) { if (expressionString == null) throw new NullPointerException("expressionString can not be null"); if (tableOrDocStringType == null) throw new NullPointerException("tableOrDocStringType can not be null"); final Expression expression; try { expression = expressionFactory.createExpression(expressionString); } catch (UndefinedParameterTypeException e) { throw registerTypeInConfiguration(expressionString, e); } RawTableTransformer&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; tableTransform = (List&amp;lt;List&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&amp;gt; raw) -&amp;gt; { DataTable dataTable = DataTable.create(raw, StepExpressionFactory.this.tableConverter); Type targetType = tableOrDocStringType.resolve(); return dataTable.convert(Object.class.equals(targetType) ? DataTable.class : targetType, transpose); }; DocStringTransformer&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; docStringTransform = (String docString) -&amp;gt; { Type targetType = tableOrDocStringType.resolve(); if (Object.class.equals(targetType)) { return docString; } List&amp;lt;List&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&amp;gt; raw = singletonList(singletonList(docString)); return DataTable.create(raw, StepExpressionFactory.this.tableConverter).convert(targetType, transpose); }; return new StepExpression(expression, docStringTransform, tableTransform); } private CucumberException registerTypeInConfiguration(String expressionString, UndefinedParameterTypeException e) { return new CucumberException(String.format("" + "Could not create a cucumber expression for '%s'.\n" + "It appears you did not register parameter type. The details are in the stacktrace below.\n" + "You can find the documentation here: &lt;https://docs.cucumber.io/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/&gt;", expressionString ), e); } private static final class ResolvedType implements TypeResolver { private final Type type; private ResolvedType(Type type) { this.type = type; } @Override public Type resolve() { return type; } } } </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:10:01

And here you'd have to add a doc string converter in the constructor and initialize it with a docStringTypeRegistry

    private final io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.ExpressionFactory expressionFactory;
    private final DataTableTypeRegistryTableConverter tableConverter;

    public StepExpressionFactory(TypeRegistry registry) {
        this.expressionFactory = new io.cucumber.cucumberexpressions.ExpressionFactory(registry.parameterTypeRegistry());
        this.tableConverter = new DataTableTypeRegistryTableConverter(registry.dataTableTypeRegistry());
    }
mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:14:13

For the implementation of the DocStringTypeRegistry you could copy parts of the DataTableTypeRegistry and trim all the parts you don't need.

Anton Deryabin
2019-08-14 06:20:18

Ok, thank you. I think, I got it

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-14 06:24:15

@mpkorstanje - the cucumber-expressions library lets users register transforms to transform a string into an arbitrary type. It‚Äôs tempting to reuse these transforms for doc strings. Do you not think we should?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:50:28

No. Cucumber expressions transform a string that matches the pattern defined in a parameter type to the type defined in the parameter type. Only the default parameter transformer can transform strings to arbitrary types.

For the doc string transforms we transform strings either to arbitrary types or we could use a transform that matches the doc string type (the ```xml bit).

mpkorstanje
2019-08-14 06:51:52

Currently we treat it as a 1x1 table and transform it to an arbitrary type using the data table cell transformer.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 14:25:09

@Aslak Helles√∏y I noticed you upgraded data table to gherkin 7. Could you please take a more conservative approach to upgrading dependencies. I would prefer to keep a pure java implementation for the jvm right now. Even if it's only test dependencies.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 15:13:05

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje can you explain why you want a more conservative approach to test dependencies? My motivation is a gradual battle-testing of new libraries, something that is high risk as runtime dependencies and low risk as test dependencies.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 15:28:05

*Thread Reply:* Test dependencies can contain flaws too. And that can impact production code. Either because a test passes when it should have failed or when used in examples - e.g. the test dependency has a feature/bug that the production versions has/doens't have.

In general I don't mind upgrading them all around a major version change though. But Gherkin >5 also uses Go so that is another pickle.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 15:49:29

*Thread Reply:* In theory you‚Äôre right, but in practice I think there is a very slim chance of this happening. If you have a doubt, make the test deliberately fail and see if the test fails with an appropriate message. Or as @matt-SmartBear says - ‚Äúnever trust a test you haven‚Äôt seen fail‚Äù.

I think the benefit we get from trying out gherkin7 in a risk-free environment (contributors‚Äô dev machines) far outweighs the risks and likelihood of false positives.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 15:52:52

*Thread Reply:* I really want to understand more about how gherkin-7 feels for developers. Any installation or runtime issues? Performance? It‚Äôs only by exposing these potential issues that we can address them.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 16:49:09

*Thread Reply:* Last time I mentioned this, it doesn't get passed security/firewall in a jar and I would consider the alternative distribution methods to be too expensive in terms of logistics. There is no off the shelve tooling for this.

The webdriver argument doesn't really work. There is no website involved. And even then the webdriver situation isn't something to aspire. It's a processes born out of necessity. Firefox and Chrome are not written in Java but have to be targeted. Gherkin is a tool in the pipeline, a means to an end, not an end on it's own. If it can't be used easily it will fall by the wayside.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 17:16:14

*Thread Reply:* You think having to do brew install cucumber-engine or similar will cause that much friction? Or even gem install cucumber-engine or similar? The thing is - we don‚Äôt have capacity to maintain all this code. And we need a way to add support for more languages in order to maintain the position as a ubiquitous tool.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 17:17:34

*Thread Reply:* I want to run an experiment and measure the uptake before binning this approach. At this point it‚Äôs pure speculation whether or not users are willing to follow a more laborious installation process.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 17:37:33

*Thread Reply:* Using gem/npm would require that we create a custom docker image for our build server that runs both java and ruby/node rather then just alpine with java.

It would also require a proxy/cache server to be setup and used. Preferably as part of the project but I have no idea if Ruby and node support project inheritance, programmatic updates, ect.

So basically I'd end up adding a bunch of exceptions every where just to even try this. I'd also have to tell 30+ mostly java devs to do this and deal with all issues. I can't afford an experiment like that. Our current setup works efficiently because it's simple and mostly standard.

And I suspect the firewall/virus scan will block the executables from npm/ruby all the same as happens with jar files.

Brew is out of the question. It's not cross platform. Has to support win/Mac/Unix. I guess you'd have to support Windows Store, Snap, Apt and what ever else packages in the Unix world.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 18:12:46

*Thread Reply:* I understand why you are doing this. But you should make the experiment safe to fail.

By starting at the core/engine/gherkin part you make it expensive to try and to stop means quite some effort was wasted.

You also need to provide more value. Otherwise inertia will keep people on the existing solution.

An experiment should also be cheap and easy to undo.

The universal formatter would be such a setup. Both Cucumber JVM and Specflow can output messages at a low cost/effort. Then you can see if people want to/can install a binary tool either via jar or manually.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-16 01:54:35

*Thread Reply:* Regarding distribution of the executables I had something simpler in mind. They can be packaged with all the popular OS package managers (brew, apt, yum, chocolatey etc) as well as being embedded in language packages (jar, npm, gem etc). We could also provide a docker image. With many different ways to install them we‚Äôd make it simple for the majority of users as they could use their favourite package manager. I realise firewall/virus scanners will still block a certain proportion of the users, but at least we should be able to provide a simple installation for those who are not encumbered by that.

All that said, you‚Äôve convinced me that we should make the experiment safe to fail and easy to undo. I agree a custom formatter would be the best way to do this. In order to have something with added value I‚Äôm thinking a new, shiny HTML formatter.

This means we have to resurrect gherkin for java/javascript/ruby and implement support for the Rule keyword. That‚Äôs probably 1-2 weeks worth of work.

How does this sound to you @mpkorstanje?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 00:33:56

*Thread Reply:* Sounds like a plan.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 00:36:36

*Thread Reply:* Another thing to consider, how often will gherkin change?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 00:39:25

*Thread Reply:* And how many people are using each language implementation.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-17 14:26:55

*Thread Reply:* Gherkin probably isn‚Äôt going to change very often. But there are other pieces of the puzzle that are a chore to maintain in many languages (cucumber expressions, formatters). And we want to add support for Markdown and Excel. And we want the effort to add support for new languages to be minimal.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 15:05:04

*Thread Reply:* But that's good. Those are all additional features. You can start a cuke implementation with just a regex.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 15:20:37

*Thread Reply:* Anyway. I did some work in Cucumber JVM to reduce the dependency surface on Gherkin.

It's just a bunch of wrappers and the the plugins now.

If you were to extract interfaces from those wrappers you could move the implementation to a separate module and use SPI to provide a Gherkin 5 and 7 parser implementation that provides the same interface to Cucumber JVM.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 15:22:19

*Thread Reply:* Then people can add maven dependency to get Gherkin 7.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 15:23:10

*Thread Reply:* It does mean the plugins will fail to work but it's a start and it should let us experiment without implementing Gherkin 7 in Java just yet.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 15:24:59

*Thread Reply:* This should only be a few days worth of work.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-17 16:01:05

*Thread Reply:* Wow that sounds like a great way to decouple the system, in a way that allows for pluggable behaviour and flexible upgrading capabilities.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-17 16:01:57

*Thread Reply:* Will this contract just return pickles? If that‚Äôs so, could the same contract be used to implement support for e.g Markdown?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:07:40

*Thread Reply:* It's a bit of a hybrid.

We need some hierarchical information to properly represent our tests in various runners.

People expect their tests to be grouped in the same way their features are.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:07:55

*Thread Reply:* So right now it is Feature --> Pickles

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:08:46

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/master/core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/feature/FeatureParser.java

Would be a good place to start looking

core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/feature/FeatureParser.java
<pre><code>package io.cucumber.core.feature; import gherkin.AstBuilder; import gherkin.Parser; import gherkin.ParserException; import gherkin.TokenMatcher; import gherkin.ast.GherkinDocument; import gherkin.events.PickleEvent; import gherkin.pickles.Compiler; import io.cucumber.core.exception.CucumberException; import io.cucumber.core.io.Resource; import java.io.IOException; import java.net.URI; import java.util.Collections; import java.util.List; import java.util.stream.Collectors; import static java.util.Objects.requireNonNull; public class FeatureParser { private FeatureParser() { } public static CucumberFeature parseResource(Resource resource) { requireNonNull(resource); URI path = resource.getPath(); String source = read(resource); try { Parser&amp;lt;GherkinDocument&amp;gt; parser = new Parser&amp;lt;&amp;gt;(new AstBuilder()); TokenMatcher matcher = new TokenMatcher(); GherkinDocument gherkinDocument = parser.parse(source, matcher); List&amp;lt;CucumberPickle&amp;gt; pickleEvents = compilePickles(gherkinDocument, resource); return new CucumberFeature(gherkinDocument, path, source, pickleEvents); } catch (ParserException e) { throw new CucumberException("Failed to parse resource at: " + path.toString(), e); } } private static String read(Resource resource) { try { return Encoding.readFile(resource); } catch (IOException e) { throw new CucumberException("Failed to read resource:" + resource.getPath(), e); } } private static List&amp;lt;CucumberPickle&amp;gt; compilePickles(GherkinDocument gherkinDocument, Resource resource) { if (gherkinDocument.getFeature() == null) { return Collections.emptyList(); } return new Compiler().compile(gherkinDocument) .stream() .map(pickle -&amp;gt; new PickleEvent(resource.getPath().toString(), pickle)) .map(pickleEvent -&amp;gt; new CucumberPickle(pickleEvent, gherkinDocument)) .collect(Collectors.toList()); } } </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:10:37

*Thread Reply:* You'd have to extract interfaces from CucumberFeature, CucumberPickle, CucumberStep, DataTableArgument and DocStringArgument.

Then you'd implement another FeatureParser for Gherkin 7.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:12:09

*Thread Reply:* If you don't know the SPI stuff, you could do it all in core and create gherkin5 and gherkin7 package instead.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:15:23

*Thread Reply:* > could the same contract be used to implement support for e.g Markdown?

Yes. But ideally you'd have all parsers use the same message protocol.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-17 16:17:44

*Thread Reply:* This is mostly a convenient internal adaptor because the gherkin 5 pickles are bit cucmber some to work with.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-15 14:34:09

I also noticed you upgraded jackson-databind to 2.10.0.pr1. This is a pre-release version of 2.10, the current mainline is 2.9. They're not intended for mass use and don't follow semantic versioning. This makes it harder for me to determine if we still follow semantic versioning.

Fortunately I'm getting rid of it now so it's not a problem but it could have ended being a nasty surprise. So please only upgrade to whole version numbers.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-15 15:14:16

*Thread Reply:* Good point @mpkorstanje - that was an oversight on my part. I use make update-dependencies and I always inspect the updates before I commit, but I must have done it too fast.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-21 02:18:09

*Thread Reply:* One of the things we need to do before we can start adopting Gherkin 7 into Cucumber-JVM is to resurrect the pure Java implementation of the parser, which was removed in v6 in favour of shelling out to Go executables.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-21 02:18:26

*Thread Reply:* (Same goes for Ruby and JavaScript btw)

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-21 02:19:41

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje has convinced me that this experiment is not safe to fail: There are too many things that could go wrong, and it could severely hurt adoption.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-08-21 02:20:32

*Thread Reply:* So while a shared runtime is still a long-term goal, we‚Äôll experiment with a shared runtime on non-core parts of Cucumber, such as a new, shiny HTML formatter (which I am currently working on).

mpkorstanje

mpkorstanje
2019-08-21 12:44:47

*Thread Reply:* For now this should do:

    public interface GherkinParser {

        /****
         ** Parses provided source to gherkin and returns it as a CucumberFeature
         **
         ** @param uri    location of the gherkin document
         ** @param source content of the gherkin document
         ** @return the parsed gherkin as a Cucumber Feature
         **/
        CucumberFeature parseFeature(URI uri, String source);

        /****
         ** Returns the Gherkin version. E.g. 5.2.1
         **
         ** @return the gherkin version.
         **/
        String version();

    }
mpkorstanje
2019-08-21 12:45:50

*Thread Reply:* You'll also have to extract interfaces from CucumberFeature, CucumberPickle and CucumberStep and implement the gherkin 7 version.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-21 12:46:27

*Thread Reply:* The version string will help us disambiguate between Gherkin parser. We'll default to the highest available.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-21 12:50:26

*Thread Reply:* You'd then have to bolt this code into the FeatureParser.

nhojpatrick
2019-08-24 14:06:23

Cucumber v1.2.5, do you this we should do a 1.2.6 release which redirects info-cukes to io.cucumber?

I just saw this in docs and thought about it ‚ÄúNote that with Cucumber-JVM v2.x, the groupId has changed from info.cukes to io.cucumber. If you cannot find a version newer than 1.2.5, change the groupId in your dependencies.‚Äù

some people might be clueless about the change, from personal experience until i wanted to help out and start contributing i was still on v1.2.5 then jumped to v4.x

nhojpatrick
2019-08-24 14:07:14

*Thread Reply:* i‚Äôm happy to prep the pom‚Äôs for the change as they will be manual creations and i‚Äôve had to do it a few times recently

mpkorstanje
2019-08-24 14:37:16

*Thread Reply:* Wait. You know how to do this? I couldnt work it out from the docs and local testing showed no results.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-24 14:37:51

*Thread Reply:* Sno yes! Please do!

nhojpatrick
2019-08-25 07:06:46

*Thread Reply:* the steps are basically; 1) build 1.2.5 but call it 1.2.6, also change the groupId to io.cucumber 2) manually craft info.cukes 1.2.6 pom to redirect to io.cucumber

then when people use versions-maven-plugin or similar they will see a 1.2.6 release

if they then upgrade to 1.2.6 they will get warnings similar to these in maven; [WARNING] The artifact info.cukes:cucumberjava:jar:1.2.6 has been relocated to io.cucumber:cucumberjava:jar:1.2.6 [WARNING] The artifact info.cukes:cucumberjunit:jar:1.2.6 has been relocated to io.cucumber:cucumberjunit:jar:1.2.6

they will then be aware of the groupId change, if they then choose to change the groupId and do versions-maven-plugin again they will see v4.7.x if done now

nhojpatrick
2019-08-25 07:07:21

*Thread Reply:* i‚Äôm basically creating two branches, the 1st needs to be pushed to maven central before the 2nd is pushed otherwise people who are keen will get build errors

nhojpatrick
2019-08-25 07:07:46

*Thread Reply:* i‚Äôm on a really slow public wifi at the moment and will push branches when home later

mpkorstanje
2019-08-25 11:03:15

*Thread Reply:* No worries.

nhojpatrick
2019-08-26 02:38:44

*Thread Reply:* so just pushed

probably easier to do a new clone and then switch to the new branch ‚Äúv1.2.6-relocation-release‚Äù

info.cukes subdir has the relocation information and very slim pom files

  • the scm tag might need to be removed so the install/deploy/release process does that
  • other deploy/release config might need to be added back in like gpg, developers, license, etc

io.cucumber subdir is a copy of 1.2.5 but with the io.cucumber groupId and versioned 1.2.6. So if people upgrade they won‚Äôt get anything new but maven etc will notify them of the groupId relocation in the build output

nhojpatrick
2019-08-26 02:40:09

*Thread Reply:* i did it this way so everything is in 1 branch with 1 tag, in 1 release, instead of separate branches

mpkorstanje
2019-08-26 02:40:34

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. Makes sense. Now to figure out how to get all that deployed. üòÑ

mlvandijk
2019-08-27 03:53:26

*Thread Reply:* Awesome @nhojpatrick!! üíú

nhojpatrick
2019-08-27 13:38:51

typetools is a dependency we need to fix to become truly JPMS, what are people views of forking the version we use, doing the JPMS changes we need, publishing with a io.cucumber.forked groupId, until the downstream project merges?

it‚Äôs only been a few days but it‚Äôs more for other downstream projects if we encounter issues with getting changes done in a timely manor are we set against that or open to doing that?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-27 22:25:11

*Thread Reply:* We can afford to wait for a few reasons.

  1. Typetools depende on JVM internals. So it may well fail on later JDKs.

  2. Should the maintainer abandon his project, it is not one I look forward too maintaining. Too complex.

  3. Cucumber Java 8 and Java are now separate modules.

I think that should let us focus on getting a small part of Cucumber working with JPMS.

If type tools is not for coming we can either remove it from cucumber java 8 or remove cucumber java 8.

By delaying the decision we can avoid spending effort and gain clarity.

mpkorstanje
2019-08-27 22:26:20

*Thread Reply:* What of pico container?

mpkorstanje
2019-08-27 23:13:35

*Thread Reply:* Not sure if this is possible but if cucumber-java, -junit and -pico and deps work with JPMS I'd consider that a milestone.

nhojpatrick
2019-08-28 05:59:28

*Thread Reply:* no issues with pico container, all my issues are with openejb at the moment

mpkorstanje
2019-08-28 06:04:19

*Thread Reply:* That's pretty good.

nhojpatrick

2nd draft https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/gherkin-v5.1.x_jpms

use java 11 to build/test, it will produce a jar compiled as 1.8 but has the jpms compiled here META-INF/versions/11/module-info.class so for people using java 11+ they can use gherin as a true module

mpkorstanje
2019-08-30 14:02:10

What happens when people use Cucumber on java 11 at the moment?

nhojpatrick
2019-08-30 14:03:29

it will work at the moment

nhojpatrick
2019-08-30 14:04:11

but using toolchain it means anyone adding gherkin as a dependency the jvm will see it as a true module not just a jar, so add it to the modules path and not the classpath

mpkorstanje
2019-08-30 14:04:46

If it's on the module path, doesn't that mean for people to use Cucumber, that Cucumber has to declare it as a module dependency?

nhojpatrick
2019-08-30 14:06:09

it means we can add java11 features and people using java 11+ can use them. people using java 1.8 won‚Äôt be able to use the java 11 features it also means if a class can be improved using java 11, we have 2 versions a java 1.8 and an improved java 11, but i‚Äôm just suggestion we use it for adding modules-info.java

2019-09-07 12:12:06

Pff. Almost there but still so much to:

Cucumber 5.0.0
==============

gherkin
 - [X] Use cucumber-parent in gherkin-jvmp-deps
 - [X] Add automatic module name to gherkin-jvmp-deps
 - [X] Release gherkin-jvmp-deps
 - [X] Use cucumber-parent in gherkin
 - [X] Add automatic module name to gherkin
 - [X] Release gherkin

cucumber-jvm
 - [X] Bump gherkin version in cucumber-jvm
 - [X] Migrate real work test case to 4.7.2
 - [X] Migrate real work test case to 5.0.0-SNAPSHOT
 - [ ] Finish release announcement
 - [ ] Release cucumber-jvm 5.0.0
 - [ ] Publish release announcement

cucumber-archetype
 - [X] Fix cucumber-archetype
 - [X] Release 4.7.2 of cucumber-archetype
 - [ ] Rename stepdefs to steps 
 - [ ] Release 5.0.0 of cucumber-archetype

cucumber-skeleton
 - [ ] Use cucumber-jvm v5
 - [ ] Rename stepdefs to steps 

docs
 - [ ] Update 10-minute tutorial
 - [ ] Update for new package structure
 - [ ] Add @ParameterType, ect
 - [ ] Update runtime options

With close to 300 commits since the last release of Cucumber v4 we're ready to release v5.0.0. This release was made possible by significant contributions from - in no particulair order; Anton Deriabin, Toepi, Ralph Kar, Marit Van Dijk, Tim Te Beek, Yatharth Zutshi, John Patrick, Vincent Psarga,

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 01:06:12

I‚Äôm going to fix https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1759 today - I‚Äôd very much like to get that into 5.0.0

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#1759 Remove or fix timeline formatter
<p>A user reported the following via direct email:</p> <hr /> <p>Issue: Older version of JQuery library within io.cucumber (cucumber-core) is red flagged during nexus scan and identified as security vulnerable and need to be upgraded.</p> <p>Details:<br /> We are currently leverage few of the MAVEN dependencies from io.cucumber for our BDD framework and we are currently noticing a nexus scan error at The Hartford (Policy issue) because of older version of JQuery library used in the cucumber library.</p> <p>Also, refer the below screenshot for the library where we are having this issue and we tried to update to the latest cucumber-core library and it is still referring to the old version of the JQuery library.</p> <p><a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1000/63943740-2ce31580-ca68-11e9-836a-67e6ccc3d77f.png">image</a></p> <hr /> <p>Now, we could easily upgrade to the latest jQuery (3.4.1 as of this writing), but how would we test that this doesn't break the formatter? From what I can tell we don't have any automated tests for the timeline formatter's JavaScript code.</p> <p>I would suggest we delete the timeline formatter from Cucumber-JVM. It can be resurrected as a standalone formatter, similar to the new <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/html-formatter">cucumber-html-formatter</a> (based on React, with a better test suite).</p> <p>I also suggest we remove the old html-formatter - it uses an even older version of jQuery.</p>
Comments
2
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm">cucumber/cucumber-jvm</a>
Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 01:55:47

*Thread Reply:* The timeline formatter works in 4.7.2 and is completely broken in master. The generated HTML page does not render and the console just displays ReferenceError: io is not defined - from somewhere in vis.min.js, which is minified.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 01:56:34

*Thread Reply:* This thing broke without anyone noticing because it doesn‚Äôt have any automated tests that run as part of CI.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 01:57:01

*Thread Reply:* It is going to be rather fiddly to fix too since there are no tests.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 01:59:30

*Thread Reply:* In short - the formatter does not meet the quality standards we need. I will timebox fixing it to 4h. If I can‚Äôt fix it in that, it may have to go (before 5.0.0 is released). I realise the functionality is useful (when it works), so I‚Äôd be happy to port it over to the new https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/html-formatter

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-11 02:02:11

*Thread Reply:* Found it! https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1357

boaty82 (https://github.com/boaty82)
#1357 Parallel support
<p>I‚Äôve previously used another implementation to deliver parallel execution of cucumber tests, however it basically wrapped up the creation and execution of <code>Runtime</code>‚Äôs, followed by the need to merge the multiple JSON/HTML etc reports that followed.</p> <p>I reviewed the current implementation and also took note of comments in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/630">Support concurrent executions of scenarios</a> also I perused all tickets related to running in <https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aissue+parallel|parallel cukes> for other insights</p> <p><strong>Main changes</strong> <strong>Added <code>--threads</code> argument to runtime options</strong></p> <p>Allows users to specify the (max) number of threads to be used to run the tests</p> <p>The actual number of threads used will be the smaller of the given <code>--threads</code> value and the number of features to be executed</p> <p>Tests are placed into a <code>Queue</code> and consumed by each thread when needed, resulting in a less deterministic order of Features being run</p> <p><strong>Ability to still run tests synchronously</strong></p> <p>There may be situations where certain Features/Scenarios need to be run in a synchronized/serial manner. To this end features/scenarios will be scanned for usages of a tag beginning with <code>@synchronized</code> (case insensitive) and will run these Feature files separately, prior to any Feature files not found to have this tag. Buckets of synchronized Feature files can also be created by using any suffix e.g. <code>@synchronized-1</code> or <code>@synchronized-bob</code></p> <p><strong>New formatter introduced <code>TimelineFormatter</code></strong></p> <p>Which produces reports using <a href="http://visjs.org/examples/timeline/groups/groups.html">vsjis.org timeline</a> to highlight which feature was run on which Thread and when.<br /> <strong>Note:</strong> the resources (js, html etc) are currently within <code>cucumber-core</code> if the PR is accepted then I‚Äôd imagine these would have to be moved out into its own project, similarly to cucumber-html.<br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8507223/39251408-18b7b1f6-489b-11e8-8426-2e842d8f2c6d.png">timeline</a><br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/files/1947348/sync_and_parallel_timeline.zip">sync<em>and</em>parallel_timeline.zip</a></p> <p><strong><code>Glue</code> / <code>RuntimeGlue</code></strong></p> <p>This was the main problem in that it serves 2 purposes.</p> <ol><li>Glue Loader/Builder</li><li>Glue Context</li> </ol> <p>Before tests are executed the glue is loaded (<code>Backend.loadGlue</code>) and then during the test run the step defs etc held in cache are modified, and hence the glue instance cannot be shared.</p> <p>Also it appears that <code>JavaBackend</code> held onto the glue reference to be used during <code>buildWorld</code> and <code>disposeWorld</code> calls - to support Java8 Lambdas</p> <p>Ideally this class/interface would be broken down into more granular APIs to reduce this issue, but this is quite a big change.</p> <p>To reduce the number of breaking changes I went with the premise that the Glue initially loaded is a template and it is cloned per thread during execution, which resulted in very few changes to be made.</p> <p>But there were 2 changes - <code>Backend.buildWorld</code> and <code>Backend.disposeWorld</code> - whereby the glue is now passed in as an argument, so it is the glue ‚Äúclone‚Äù applicable to the running thread. This means any other implementations of <code>Backend</code> outside of this repository need updating.</p> <p>Unfortunately, I could not think of another way around this, but happy to discuss further.</p> <p><strong>Others Issues encountered / rectified</strong></p> <p>‚Ä¢ <code>Stats</code><br /> Was not thread safe ‚Ä¢ <code>UndefinedStepsTracker</code><br /> Was not thread safe ‚Ä¢ <code>EventBus</code> thread safety<br /> <code>registerHandlerFor</code> is not thread safe, originally I updated it to be but couldn‚Äôt find any sign of sharing instances - so I reverted the change ‚Ä¢ <code>UnreportedStepExecutor</code> implementation<br /> Extracted this out of <code>Runner</code> and into its own class<br /> Glue is injected, but as there was no real usage of this functionality I couldn‚Äôt tell if the Glue ‚Äútemplate‚Äù was OK to be injected or not - I assume it is but have left a TODO comment for review/discussion ‚Ä¢ <code>LocalizedXStreams</code> not thread safe<br /> Internal Map to hold cache of <code>LocalizedXStream</code> was not threadsafe ‚Ä¢ <code>Formatter</code>s output being incorrect as not thread safe<br /> I have updated all Formatter implementations located in <code>cucumber-jvm</code>, specifically<br /> <code>AndroidInstrumentationReporter</code>, <code>HTMLFormatter</code>, <code>JSONFormatter</code>, <code>JUnitFormatter</code>, <code>PrettyFormatter</code>, <code>RerunFormatter</code>, <code>TestNGFormatter</code>, <code>UsageFormatter</code><br /> to be thread safe<br /> Also added a note to the javadocs.<br /> <strong>Note</strong> any impl's in other repositories still need reviewing/updating ‚Ä¢ <code>TestSourcesModel</code> updated this to be thread safe in the event any instances are shared (none in cucumber-jvm repo) ‚Ä¢ Update <code>ObjectFactory</code> implementations to be thread safe<br /> Specifically<br /> <code>DefaultJavaObjectFactory</code>, <code>GuiceFactory</code>, <code>NeedleFactory</code>, <code>OpenEJBObjectFactory</code>, <code>OsgiObjectFactoryBase</code>, <code>PicoFactory</code>, <code>WeldFactory</code> all were minor changes so I felt new tests were not needed<br /> <code>SpringFactory</code> appeared to be threadsafe already so I added some tests to <code>SpringFactoryTest</code> and it proved to be the case<br /> <strong>Note</strong> any impl's in other repositories still need reviewing/updating</p>
Comments
34

intellij link for io.cucumber.java8 lambdas issues https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-219739

YouTrack
When steps are defined using io.cucumber.java.en.Given intllij does not recognize it in the feature file. Only when the deprecated cucumber.api.java.en.Given is used is the step identified as implemented. : IDEA-219739
Example: Given a feature file with the following content: Feature: Is it Friday yet? Everybody wants to know when it's Friday Scenario: Sunday isn't Friday Given today is Sunday When‚Ä¶
Original URL: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-219739

nhojpatrick
2019-09-13 02:29:40

the only bit i‚Äôm clueless about is how to get travis and toolchains working together‚Ä¶ so for all the branches i‚Äôve recently pushed should do this;

1) install/setup openjdk 1.8 2) install/setup openjdk 11 3) configure toolchains.xml for 1.8 and 11 location 4) set java home to 1.8 i.e. java -version reports 1.8 2) mvn clean install 3) set java home to 1.8 i.e. java -version reports 11 4) mvn clean install

to release; 1) install/setup openjdk 1.8 2) install/setup openjdk 11 3) configure toolchains.xml for 1.8 and 11 location 4) set java home to 1.8 i.e. java -version reports 1.8 5) mvn clean deploy

rasklaad (https://github.com/rasklaad)
#1768 WIP Lambda equivalent for @ParameterType annotation
<p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>‚òëÔ∏é @DocStringType lambda implementation ‚òëÔ∏é @ParameterType lambda implementation ‚òëÔ∏é @DataTableType lambda inplementation ‚òê ParameterType with multiple capture groups ‚òê Javadocs</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/issues/1764">#1764</a></p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>‚òëÔ∏é docstring tests ‚òëÔ∏é parametertype tests ‚òëÔ∏é datatable type tests</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>‚òê Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue). ‚òëÔ∏é New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). ‚òê Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>‚òëÔ∏é I've added tests for my code. ‚òëÔ∏é My change requires a change to the documentation. ‚òê I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>

mpkorstanje
2019-10-07 08:29:13

*Thread Reply:* @seb found the problem with the shouty example and spring

When declaring beans in the cucumber.xml file you don't get the annotation driven configuration.

So you have to specify the scope explicitly:

    &lt;bean class="shouty.Shouty" autowire-candidate="true" scope="cucumber-glue"/&gt;

Or if you do want to use annotation driven configuration:

    &lt;context:annotation-config/&gt;
    &lt;context:component-scan base-package="shouty"/&gt;

And finally you can also this entirely annotation based without example by putting the configuration on the step definitions.

@ContextConfiguration(classes = Shouty.class)
public class ShoutSteps {
seb
2019-10-07 08:32:59

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, @mpkorstanje.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-10-07 09:23:13

*Thread Reply:* Brilliant @mpkorstanje!

Aslak Helles√∏y
2019-09-26 08:35:57

  • io.cucumber.core.stepexpression.TypeRegistry
  • io.cucumber.core.api.TypeRegistry This caused a little friction since I wasn‚Äôt sure which one to use.
